1.meaning_en: A person who walks about in their sleep.
usage_sentences: The clinic treats patients who are somnambulists.
Shakespeare's Lady Macbeth is a famous fictional somnambulist.

1.meaning_en: Present everywhere at the same time.
usage_sentences: To a child, a loving mother is an omnipresent force.
The problem of pollution has become omnipresent in the modern world.

1.meaning_en: A person who knows and is able to use several languages.
usage_sentences: The tour guide was a polyglot, fluently switching between languages.
As a polyglot, she found it easy to work for international organizations.

1.meaning_en: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
usage_sentences: After years of betrayal, he became a bitter misanthrope.
The main character is a wealthy misanthrope who prefers books.

1.meaning_en: A person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by generous donations.
usage_sentences: The new hospital wing was funded by a wealthy philanthropist.
She was a noted philanthropist, dedicating her fortune to education.

1.meaning_en: A person who collects or has a great love of books.
usage_sentences: His massive library was a clear indication he was a true bibliophile.
The old bibliophile spent weekends searching for rare first editions.

1.meaning_en: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
usage_sentences: While he is a great expert, his advice is not infallible.
The new computer system was marketed as being completely infallible.
1.origin: From late Latin 'infallibilis', from 'in-' (not) and 'fallibilis' (liable to err).

1.meaning_en: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
usage_sentences: With those dark clouds gathering, rain seems inevitable.
Change is an inevitable part of life.

1.meaning_en: A connoisseur of good food; a person with a discerning palate.
usage_sentences: The restaurant is a favorite among local gourmets.
He considered himself a gourmet, delighting in exotic meals.

1.meaning_en: A person who never drinks alcohol.
usage_sentences: He was a strict teetotaler and only drank water at parties.
The organization was founded by a group of dedicated teetotalers.
1.origin: From the mid-19th century, from the emphatic use of the letter 'T' in 'total'.

1.meaning_en: A person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining.
usage_sentences: She remained a stoic throughout her long illness.
The old soldier had a stoic expression on his face as he received the news.
1.origin: From Greek 'Stōïkos', referring to the 'Stoa Poikilē' in Athens where Zeno taught.

1.meaning_en: A person who has a selfless concern for the well-being of others.
usage_sentences: The nurse was a true altruist, often working extra shifts without pay.
An altruist by nature, she dedicated her life to helping the homeless.
1.origin: From French 'altruisme', formed from Italian 'altrui' (of others).

1.meaning_en: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
usage_sentences: He was a fastidious writer, often spending hours on a single sentence.
Her fastidious attention to detail made her an excellent editor.

1.meaning_en: A person or their tendencies not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.
usage_sentences: He is an incorrigible flirt who will never settle down.
The student was an incorrigible prankster, constantly disrupting the class.

1.meaning_en: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
usage_sentences: Technology is not a panacea for all our problems.
He was searching for a panacea that would solve the company's financial woes.

1.meaning_en: A person fond of company; sociable.
usage_sentences: He was a popular and gregarious man, always surrounded by friends.
Dolphins are gregarious animals that live in large pods.

1.meaning_en: A person who disbelieves or lacks belief in the existence of God or gods.
usage_sentences: As an atheist, he did not participate in any religious ceremonies.
The famous author was a vocal atheist and often wrote about her views.

1.meaning_en: An expert judge in matters of taste.
usage_sentences: She is a connoisseur of fine wines.
The art gallery relied on the connoisseur to verify the painting's authenticity.

1.meaning_en: A person whose personality has a balance of extrovert and introvert features.
usage_sentences: As an ambivert, she enjoys social gatherings but also needs her quiet time alone.
Most people are not pure introverts or extroverts, but rather fall in the ambivert spectrum.
1.origin: From Latin 'ambi-' (on both sides) and 'vertere' (to turn).

1.meaning_en: A government by the wealthy.
usage_sentences: Critics argue that the country is becoming a plutocracy.
A plutocracy can lead to policies that benefit the wealthy.

1.meaning_en: A state of disorder due to absence of authority.
usage_sentences: The country descended into anarchy after the government collapsed.
Without a leader, the project team fell into a state of anarchy.

1.meaning_en: Having unlimited power; able to do anything.
usage_sentences: In many mythologies, the supreme deity is described as omnipotent.
The dictator sought to become an omnipotent ruler.

1.meaning_en: Knowing everything.
usage_sentences: The novel is told from the perspective of an omniscient narrator.
If I were omniscient, I would know the winning lottery numbers.

1.meaning_en: Fit to be eaten.
usage_sentences: Not all mushrooms are edible; some are highly poisonous.
The chef decorated the cake with edible flowers.

1.meaning_en: Not clear enough to be read.
usage_sentences: The doctor's handwriting was completely illegible.
Years of weathering had made the inscription on the tombstone illegible.

1.meaning_en: Not able to be forgotten or removed.
usage_sentences: The experience left an indelible mark on his memory.
She used an indelible marker to sign the photograph.

1.meaning_en: Too powerful to be defeated or overcome.
usage_sentences: The champion boxer seemed invincible until his final match.
With their advanced technology, the army appeared invincible.

1.meaning_en: Safe to drink.
usage_sentences: The mountain stream provided fresh, potable water.
After the flood, finding potable water became a major challenge.

1.meaning_en: Able to be heard.
usage_sentences: He spoke so softly that his voice was barely audible.
The sound of the distant thunder was clearly audible.

1.meaning_en: The practice of being married to one person at a time.
usage_sentences: Many cultures practice monogamy as the standard for relationships.
The swans are known for their lifelong monogamy.

1.meaning_en: The practice of having more than one spouse at the same time.
usage_sentences: Polygamy is legal in some parts of the world.
The documentary explored the lives of families in a polygamy.

1.meaning_en: A person who is self-centered or selfish.
usage_sentences: The egoist cared only about his own success, not the team's.
His constant boasting revealed him to be a true egoist.

1.meaning_en: Someone who believes that all events are predetermined and therefore inevitable.
usage_sentences: As a fatalist, he accepted his misfortunes without complaint.
A fatalist believes there's no point in trying to change the future.

1.meaning_en: A person who tends to be hopeful and confident about the future.
usage_sentences: Even in difficult times, she remained a steadfast optimist.
An optimist sees the glass as half full.

1.meaning_en: A person who tends to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.
usage_sentences: The pessimist was sure they would miss their flight.
He was too much of a pessimist to enjoy the surprise party.

1.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of confined places.
usage_sentences: His claustrophobia made it impossible for him to ride in an elevator.
She felt a wave of claustrophobia in the crowded subway car.
1.origin: From Latin 'claustrum' (a bolt, a place shut in) + '-phobia'.

1.meaning_en: Accept something reluctantly but without protest.
usage_sentences: She will acquiesce in any decision he makes.
The rebels were forced to acquiesce to the terms of the treaty.
1.origin: From Latin 'acquiescere', meaning 'to find rest in'.

1.meaning_en: Make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
usage_sentences: He couldn't prevent her pain, only alleviate it.
The medicine is designed to alleviate symptoms.

1.meaning_en: Combine or unite to form one organization or structure.
usage_sentences: The two companies plan to amalgamate next year.
He amalgamated his collection of stamps with hers.

1.meaning_en: Make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.
usage_sentences: The new policies are intended to ameliorate the effects of the recession.
He wanted to ameliorate the present suffering.

1.meaning_en: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists.
usage_sentences: The sword is an anachronism in modern warfare.
Her old-fashioned ideas were an anachronism in the modern world.

1.meaning_en: Living in trees; relating to trees.
usage_sentences: Monkeys are arboreal animals.
The biologist studied the arboreal habitats of the rainforest.

1.meaning_en: Make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense.
usage_sentences: The letter assuaged the fears of most members.
He tried to assuage the guilt of wrongdoing by doing right.
1.origin: From Old French 'assouagier', based on Latin 'ad-' (to) + 'suavis' (sweet).

1.meaning_en: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks.
usage_sentences: It was an audacious plan to cross the mountains in winter.
The audacious girl climbed the tallest tree in the park.

1.meaning_en: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
usage_sentences: He was driven by avarice.
The corporate world is often criticized for its avarice.

1.meaning_en: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
usage_sentences: The bellicose hockey player was always getting into fights.
His bellicose attitude was not appreciated by his colleagues.

1.meaning_en: The act or offense of speaking sacrilegiously about God or sacred things.
usage_sentences: He was accused of blasphemy for his controversial new book.
In some countries, blasphemy is a serious crime.

1.meaning_en: Noisy, energetic, and cheerful; rowdy.
usage_sentences: A large and boisterous crowd attended the concert.
The boisterous children were running and shouting in the playground.

1.meaning_en: The art of producing decorative handwriting or lettering with a pen or brush.
usage_sentences: The wedding invitations were written in beautiful calligraphy.
He studied calligraphy for many years to perfect his script.

1.meaning_en: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
usage_sentences: The capricious weather made it difficult to plan the picnic.
He was a capricious and unreliable friend.

2.meaning_en: A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
usage_sentences: The enzyme acted as a catalyst in the reaction.
His speech was the catalyst for the protest.

2.meaning_en: The use of many words where fewer would do, especially in a deliberate attempt to be vague or evasive.
usage_sentences: The politician's speech was full of circumlocution.
I hate the circumlocution of legal documents.

2.meaning_en: Having knowledge or being aware of.
usage_sentences: He was cognizant of the risks involved.
She was not cognizant of her own biases.

2.meaning_en: A confusing and difficult problem or question.
usage_sentences: The team was faced with a difficult conundrum.
How to solve this problem is a real conundrum.

2.meaning_en: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things.
usage_sentences: The credulous man was easily tricked by the scam artist.
Credulous people are often the victims of hoaxes.

2.meaning_en: A person who believes that people are motivated purely by self-interest rather than acting for honorable or unselfish reasons.
usage_sentences: A cynic might say that the charity is just a way to get tax breaks.
He's too much of a cynic to believe in true love.

2.meaning_en: Causing harm or damage.
usage_sentences: Smoking has a deleterious effect on your health.
The new policy had a deleterious impact on the environment.

2.meaning_en: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices rather than by using rational argument.
usage_sentences: The demagogue used fear to control the people.
His speeches were full of the rhetoric of a demagogue.

2.meaning_en: Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
usage_sentences: The novel was too didactic to be enjoyable.
He had a didactic way of speaking.

2.meaning_en: Regard or represent as being of little worth.
usage_sentences: He never missed an opportunity to disparage his competitors.
It is not fair to disparage the efforts of the volunteers.
2.origin: From Old French 'desparagier' (marry someone of unequal rank).

2.meaning_en: Lasting for a very short time.
usage_sentences: Fame in the world of pop music is largely ephemeral.
The beauty of the cherry blossoms is ephemeral.

2.meaning_en: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
usage_sentences: She accepted both the good and the bad with equanimity.
He faced the crisis with his usual equanimity.

2.meaning_en: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
usage_sentences: The erudite professor gave a fascinating lecture on ancient history.
She could turn any conversation into an erudite discussion.

2.meaning_en: A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt when referring to something unpleasant or embarrassing.
usage_sentences: 'Passed away' is a euphemism for 'died'.
The company used euphemisms to hide the fact that it was firing people.

2.meaning_en: Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
usage_sentences: The new law will only exacerbate the problem of unemployment.
His angry words exacerbated the already tense situation.

2.meaning_en: Show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: The new evidence helped to exculpate the defendant.
He was exculpated of all charges.

2.meaning_en: Pressing; demanding.
usage_sentences: The exigent circumstances required immediate action.
He had to deal with the exigent needs of the refugees.

2.meaning_en: Extend the application of (a method or conclusion, especially one based on statistics) to an unknown situation by assuming that existing trends will continue.
usage_sentences: We can extrapolate the future growth of the company from its past performance.
It is difficult to extrapolate from this small sample.

2.meaning_en: Silly and pointless.
usage_sentences: He made a fatuous comment that annoyed everyone.
The fatuous grin on his face was irritating.

2.meaning_en: (Of something considered wrong or immoral) conspicuously or obviously offensive.
usage_sentences: It was a flagrant violation of the rules.
The politician's flagrant lie was caught on camera.

2.meaning_en: Happening by accident or chance rather than design.
usage_sentences: It was a fortuitous meeting that changed the course of her life.
The discovery of the new drug was purely fortuitous.

2.meaning_en: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
usage_sentences: The garrulous old man told us his life story.
She was so garrulous that no one could get a word in edgewise.

2.meaning_en: Use gestures, especially dramatic ones, instead of speaking or to emphasize one's words.
usage_sentences: He gesticulated wildly to get our attention.
The speaker gesticulated with his hands to make his point.

2.meaning_en: A person who enjoys eating and often eats too much.
usage_sentences: The gourmand ordered the largest steak on the menu.
He was a gourmand who loved rich, heavy food.

2.meaning_en: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.
usage_sentences: The politician's grandiloquent speech was full of empty promises.
He had a grandiloquent way of speaking that annoyed some people.

2.meaning_en: Done without good reason; uncalled for.
usage_sentences: The film was criticized for its gratuitous violence.
She made a gratuitous comment that was completely unnecessary.

2.meaning_en: A lengthy and aggressive speech.
usage_sentences: The politician delivered a long harangue against his opponents.
She was not in the mood for another harangue from her mother.

2.meaning_en: A person who believes that the pursuit of pleasure is the most important thing in life; a pleasure-seeker.
usage_sentences: He was a hedonist who lived for the moment.
The hedonist spent his days in luxury and self-indulgence.

2.meaning_en: A person believing in or practicing religious heresy.
usage_sentences: The heretic was excommunicated from the church.
He was considered a heretic for questioning the established beliefs.

2.meaning_en: A pause or gap in a sequence, series, or process.
usage_sentences: The band is taking a hiatus from touring.
There was a brief hiatus in the conversation.

2.meaning_en: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
usage_sentences: She had a histrionic reaction to the news.
The actor's histrionic performance was not very convincing.

2.meaning_en: A religious discourse that is intended primarily for spiritual edification rather than doctrinal instruction; a sermon.
usage_sentences: The priest delivered a homily on the importance of forgiveness.
She was tired of her father's homilies about the importance of hard work.

2.meaning_en: A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
usage_sentences: The artist was an iconoclast who challenged the traditional notions of beauty.
He was an iconoclast who was not afraid to speak his mind.

2.meaning_en: The worship of idols.
usage_sentences: The ancient religion practiced idolatry.
The worship of celebrities is a modern form of idolatry.

2.meaning_en: About to happen.
usage_sentences: The storm is imminent.
He was in imminent danger of being fired.

2.meaning_en: Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
usage_sentences: The laws of physics are immutable.
Her decision to leave the company was immutable.

2.meaning_en: Not feeling or showing emotion.
usage_sentences: He remained impassive as the verdict was read.
The poker player had an impassive expression on his face.

2.meaning_en: Having little or no money.
usage_sentences: The impecunious student had to work two jobs to pay for his tuition.
He came from an impecunious family.

2.meaning_en: Assuming power or authority without justification; arrogant and domineering.
usage_sentences: The imperious manager was not well-liked by his employees.
She had an imperious way of speaking that made people feel small.

2.meaning_en: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
usage_sentences: He made an impetuous decision that he later regretted.
She was an impetuous young woman who often got into trouble.

2.meaning_en: Unable to be placated.
usage_sentences: He was an implacable enemy.
The implacable dictator refused to negotiate with the rebels.

2.meaning_en: Dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive); call into question.
usage_sentences: He impugned the integrity of the witness.
The defense attorney tried to impugn the testimony of the prosecution's star witness.

2.meaning_en: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
usage_sentences: The inchoate idea for a new novel was slowly taking shape in her mind.
The project was still in its inchoate stages.

2.meaning_en: Mark or decorate (an object or surface) with a cut or a series of cuts.
usage_sentences: The jeweler incised the ring with a beautiful design.
The ancient pottery was incised with geometric patterns.

2.meaning_en: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
usage_sentences: The indolent cat slept all day.
He was an indolent student who never did his homework.

2.meaning_en: Lacking the ability or strength to move.
usage_sentences: The inert body of the victim lay on the floor.
The economy was inert for several years.

2.meaning_en: (Of a person or action) innocent and unsuspecting.
usage_sentences: She had an ingenuous smile that made everyone trust her.
The ingenuous young man was easily tricked by the con artist.

2.meaning_en: Tending to obstruct or harm.
usage_sentences: The inimical policies of the government led to widespread protests.
He had an inimical attitude towards his colleagues.

2.meaning_en: Not harmful or offensive.
usage_sentences: The innocuous-looking snake was actually very poisonous.
He made an innocuous comment that was taken the wrong way.

2.meaning_en: Lacking flavor.
usage_sentences: The soup was insipid and tasteless.
The insipid conversation bored everyone.

3.meaning_en: Unable to pay debts owed.
usage_sentences: The company was declared insolvent.
He was in danger of becoming insolvent.

3.meaning_en: Ignorant of or uninterested in cultures, ideas, or peoples outside one's own experience.
usage_sentences: The island community was very insular.
He had an insular view of the world.

3.meaning_en: Hard to control or deal with.
usage_sentences: The intractable problem of poverty has no easy solution.
The intractable child refused to listen to his parents.

3.meaning_en: Unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
usage_sentences: The intransigent politician refused to compromise.
He was intransigent in his opposition to the new law.

3.meaning_en: Overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with.
usage_sentences: We were inundated with requests for help.
The office was inundated with phone calls.

3.meaning_en: Accustom (someone) to something, especially something unpleasant.
usage_sentences: The soldiers were inured to the hardships of war.
He was inured to the criticism of his opponents.
3.origin: From an Old French phrase 'en ure' (in practice).

3.meaning_en: Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
usage_sentences: The irascible old man was always shouting at the children.
She was known for her irascible temper.

3.meaning_en: Showing or feeling hesitancy; uncertain.
usage_sentences: He was irresolute about what to do next.
The irresolute leader was unable to make a decision.

3.meaning_en: Traveling from place to place.
usage_sentences: The itinerant preacher traveled from town to town.
He was an itinerant worker who never stayed in one place for long.

3.meaning_en: Abandon or discard (someone or something that is no longer wanted).
usage_sentences: The company had to jettison its unprofitable divisions.
He jettisoned his old friends when he became famous.

3.meaning_en: Extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy.
usage_sentences: The politician's speech was full of jingoism.
Jingoism can lead to war.
3.origin: From a song in a British music hall.

3.meaning_en: Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
usage_sentences: The artist juxtaposed the bright colors with the dark shadows.
The essay juxtaposed the two different cultures.
3.origin: From French 'juxtaposer', from Latin 'juxta' (next) + French 'poser' (to place).

3.meaning_en: (Of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words.
usage_sentences: He was a laconic man who never said more than was necessary.
She gave a laconic reply to his long question.
3.origin: From Greek 'Lakonikos', from 'Lakon' (a Laconian, a Spartan).

3.meaning_en: Generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others.
usage_sentences: The wealthy philanthropist was known for his largesse.
The company's largesse was appreciated by the community.

3.meaning_en: Praise (a person or their achievements) highly, especially in a public context.
usage_sentences: The author was lauded for his new novel.
The firefighters were lauded for their bravery.

3.meaning_en: Skillful use of one's hands when performing conjuring tricks.
usage_sentences: The magician's legerdemain amazed the audience.
He was a master of legerdemain.
3.origin: From French 'léger de main' (light of hand).

3.meaning_en: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.
usage_sentences: The hot weather made everyone feel lethargic.
He was a lethargic student who never participated in class.

3.meaning_en: The treatment of a serious matter with humor or in a manner lacking due respect.
usage_sentences: The levity of his comments was not appropriate for the solemn occasion.
She tried to inject some levity into the tense situation.

3.meaning_en: A published false statement that is damaging to a person's reputation; a written defamation.
usage_sentences: The newspaper was sued for libel.
The politician claimed that the article was a libel.

3.meaning_en: (Especially of a person's body) thin, supple, and graceful.
usage_sentences: The lithe dancer moved across the stage with ease.
She had a lithe and graceful body.

3.meaning_en: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
usage_sentences: The loquacious talk show host never ran out of things to say.
She was a loquacious child who loved to tell stories.

3.meaning_en: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
usage_sentences: He gave a lucid explanation of the complex theory.
The lucid dream felt completely real.

3.meaning_en: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
usage_sentences: The lugubrious music made everyone feel depressed.
He had a lugubrious expression on his face.

3.meaning_en: Full of or shedding light; bright or shining, especially in the dark.
usage_sentences: The luminous moon lit up the night sky.
The luminous paint glowed in the dark.

3.meaning_en: Disturbing and horrifying because of involvement with or depiction of death and injury.
usage_sentences: The macabre story was about a haunted house.
He had a macabre sense of humor.
3.origin: From French 'macabre', probably from the title of a medieval French play.

3.meaning_en: Cunning, scheming, and unscrupulous, especially in politics or in advancing one's career.
usage_sentences: The Machiavellian politician would do anything to gain power.
He was known for his Machiavellian tactics.
3.origin: From the name of Niccolò Machiavelli, an Italian statesman and writer.

3.meaning_en: A powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river.
usage_sentences: The ship was caught in a maelstrom.
The country was in a maelstrom of political unrest.

3.meaning_en: Generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person.
usage_sentences: The magnanimous winner congratulated his opponent.
She was magnanimous in her victory.

3.meaning_en: Having or showing a wish to do evil to others.
usage_sentences: The malevolent witch cast a spell on the princess.
He had a malevolent look in his eyes.

3.meaning_en: (Of a metal or other material) able to be hammered or pressed permanently out of shape without breaking or cracking.
usage_sentences: Gold is a malleable metal.
The young mind is malleable and easily influenced.

3.meaning_en: Clear or obvious to the eye or mind.
usage_sentences: His guilt was manifest to all who saw him.
The manifest destiny of the country was to expand westward.

3.meaning_en: A strict disciplinarian, especially in the armed forces.
usage_sentences: The drill sergeant was a martinet who demanded perfection.
She was a martinet who ran her household with military precision.
3.origin: From the name of Jean Martinet, a 17th-century French drillmaster.

3.meaning_en: An unorthodox or independent-minded person.
usage_sentences: The maverick politician was not afraid to challenge the party line.
He was a maverick who did things his own way.
3.origin: From the name of Samuel A. Maverick, a 19th-century Texas rancher who did not brand his cattle.

3.meaning_en: (Of a voice or words) sweet or musical; pleasant to hear.
usage_sentences: The mellifluous voice of the singer captivated the audience.
She spoke in a mellifluous tone.

3.meaning_en: Not telling the truth; lying.
usage_sentences: The mendacious politician was caught in a lie.
He gave a mendacious account of what had happened.

3.meaning_en: (Of a person) subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.
usage_sentences: The mercurial actor was known for his temper tantrums.
She had a mercurial temperament.
3.origin: From Latin 'mercurialis' (relating to the god Mercury).

3.meaning_en: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
usage_sentences: The meticulous surgeon left no room for error.
She was meticulous in her work.

3.meaning_en: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
usage_sentences: The misanthrope lived alone in a cabin in the woods.
He was a misanthrope who hated everyone.

3.meaning_en: Make less severe, serious, or painful.
usage_sentences: The new law is intended to mitigate the effects of climate change.
He tried to mitigate the damage caused by his mistake.

3.meaning_en: Appease the anger or anxiety of (someone).
usage_sentences: He tried to mollify the angry crowd.
She was mollified by his apology.

3.meaning_en: Lack of variety and interest; tedious repetition and routine.
usage_sentences: The monotony of his job was starting to get to him.
She broke the monotony of her life by taking up a new hobby.

3.meaning_en: (Of a person) at the point of death.
usage_sentences: The moribund patient was surrounded by his family.
The moribund company was on the verge of bankruptcy.

3.meaning_en: Sullen and ill-tempered.
usage_sentences: The morose man sat alone in the corner.
She was in a morose mood.

3.meaning_en: Lacking interest or excitement; dull.
usage_sentences: She was tired of her mundane life.
The mundane task of washing the dishes had to be done.

3.meaning_en: (Of a gift or sum of money) larger or more generous than is usual or necessary.
usage_sentences: The munificent donation helped to build the new hospital.
He was a munificent benefactor to the arts.

3.meaning_en: A countless or extremely great number.
usage_sentences: There are a myriad of stars in the night sky.
The city has a myriad of attractions to offer.

3.meaning_en: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization.
usage_sentences: The company reached its nadir when it had to file for bankruptcy.
He was at the nadir of his career.

3.meaning_en: (Especially of a process or organization) just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential.
usage_sentences: The nascent company was still struggling to find its place in the market.
He was a nascent politician with a bright future.

3.meaning_en: (Of a concept or idea) unclear, vague, or ill-defined.
usage_sentences: He had a nebulous idea of what he wanted to do with his life.
The plan was too nebulous to be put into action.

3.meaning_en: (Typically of an action or activity) wicked or criminal.
usage_sentences: The nefarious plot to overthrow the government was foiled.
He was a nefarious character who could not be trusted.
